\documentclass[english]{article}
\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
\usepackage[latin9]{inputenc}
\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
The robot can be reperesented by $x_{t}=(x_{t,},y_{t,}\theta_{t})^{T}$
where $x_{t}$ and $y_{t}$are the robot's two dimensional coordinates
and $\theta_{t}$ is the robot's orientation. 

For our algorithm we adopt our motion model of Teddy N. Yap and Christian
R. Shelton. 

$x_{t}=x_{t-1}+D_{t}cos(\theta_{t-1}+\frac{T_{t}}{2})$

$y_{t}=y_{t-1}+D_{t}sin(\theta_{t-1}+\frac{T_{t}}{2})$

The noise model is described below

$D_{t}\sim\mathcal{{N}}(d_{t},d_{t}^{2}\sigma_{D_{d}}^{2}+r_{t}^{2}\sigma_{D_{r}}^{2}+\sigma_{D_{1}}^{2})$

$T_{t}\sim\mathcal{{N}}(r_{t},d_{t}^{2}\sigma_{T_{d}}^{2}+r_{t}^{2}\sigma_{T_{r}}^{2}+\sigma_{T_{1}}^{2})$

$d_{t}$ and $r_{t}$ are the translational and rotation of the robot.
$\sigma_{A_{b}}$ decribes the contribution of odometry term b to
the variance of the distribution over A. $\sigma_{D_{1}}$ and $\sigma_{T_{1}}$are
used to take into account the independent errors that are not proportional
to translation and rotation of the robot. Our algroithm intends to
learn the following parameters $\sigma_{D_{d}}^{2}$,$\sigma_{T_{d}}^{2}$,$\sigma_{D_{r}}^{2}$,$\sigma_{T_{r}}^{2}$,$\sigma_{D_{1}}^{2}$,$\sigma_{T_{1}}^{2}$.
\end{document}
